Salty: A flavor profile from soy sauce, salt, or fermented seafood, providing depth and seasoning.
Moderate seasoning: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to moderate seasoning, often described as korean-style, traditional, ingredients.
Vegetables: Fresh vegetables like cabbage, spinach, bean sprouts, and radish, essential in Korean meals.
Red: A reddish color, often from gochujang, gochugaru, or other red ingredients.
Savory: A rich, umami flavor profile from fermented ingredients like soy sauce, doenjang, or fish sauce.
Bowl: Served in a bowl, typically for soups, stews, or rice dishes.
Stewed: Slow-cooked in liquid, allowing flavors to meld and ingredients to become tender and flavorful.
Fried: Cooked in hot oil, creating a crispy, golden exterior while maintaining tender interior.
Soup: A liquid-based dish, often served as part of a meal, ranging from light broths to hearty stews.
Crispy: A texture characterized by a crunchy, brittle exterior, often achieved through frying or grilling.
Simmered: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to simmered, often described as traditional, soup/stew, featuring.
Stew: A thick, hearty dish cooked slowly in liquid, with rich, concentrated flavors.
Spicy: A flavor profile characterized by Gochujang (red chili paste) or red pepper powder (gochugaru), creating a fiery, pungent heat that is a signature of Korean cuisine.
Tender: A soft, easily chewable texture, often from slow cooking or marination.
Plate: Served on a plate, typically for dry dishes or grilled items.
Red spicy broth: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to red spicy broth, often described as traditional, soup/stew, featuring.
Rice: The staple grain of Korean cuisine, served with almost every meal, often sticky short-grain rice.
Deep-fried: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to deep-fried, often described as crispy, fried, korean-style.
Seafood: Fresh fish, shrimp, squid, and other marine ingredients, common in coastal Korean cuisine.
White rice: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to white rice, often described as rice-based, various, toppings,.
Braised: Slow-cooked in liquid, allowing flavors to meld and ingredients to become tender and flavorful.
Kimchi: Fermented vegetables, most commonly napa cabbage, seasoned with chili and garlic, a Korean staple.
Sour: A tangy flavor profile from vinegar, fermented foods, or citrus elements.
Fermented: Preserved through fermentation, developing complex, tangy flavors and beneficial probiotics.
Marinated: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to marinated, often described as marinated, sauce, flavorful.
Grilled: Cooked over an open flame or on a grill, imparting a smoky, charred flavor and crispy texture.
Beef: A premium protein in Korean cooking, often marinated and grilled, or used in soups and stews.
Pork: A versatile meat used in Korean BBQ, stews, and various dishes, especially popular as pork belly.
Noodle: Various types including wheat, buckwheat, and sweet potato noodles, used in soups and stir-fries.
Sesame seeds: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to sesame seeds, often described as sesame, traditional, side.
Wheat noodles: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to wheat noodles, often described as featuring, flavorful, broth.
Egg: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to egg, often described as korean-style, crispy, fried.
Chicken: A common poultry ingredient in Korean cuisine, used in soups, stews, grilled dishes, and fried preparations.
Sweet: A flavor profile featuring sweetness from sugar, honey, or fruits like pear, creating a balanced taste.
Pan-fried: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to pan-fried, often described as savory, pancake, made.
Tofu: Soft or firm soybean curd, a protein-rich ingredient used in stews and side dishes.
Pan: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to pan, often described as savory, pancake, made.
Stir-fried: Quickly cooked in a hot pan with oil, maintaining crisp textures and vibrant colors.
Mild sweet: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to mild sweet, often described as sweet, sauce, beef.
Steamed: Cooked with steam, preserving natural flavors and nutrients while keeping ingredients moist.
Egg garnish: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to egg garnish, often described as topped, egg,, vegetables,.
Sautéed: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to sautéed, often described as made, spicy,, hearty.
Boiled: Cooked in boiling liquid, often used for soups and noodles, creating a clear, clean flavor.
Rice porridge: A characteristic of Korean cuisine related to rice porridge, often described as rice-based, various, toppings,.
